text: hey everyone I'm gonna show you another
method to dry aerogel so in my previous
videos I showed a methanol bath and then
an exchange into liquid co2 and then co2
into supercritical co2 where we can
remove it without destroying the aerogel
structure but there's an easier way
actually instead of transferring into
liquid co2 we can make the methanol
itself go supercritical so apparently
this is how the first aerogels were made
just because the process is actually
simpler in a way the problem is that
it's a little more dangerous because the
methanol has to be brought up to over
460 degrees F over 1200 psi so having a
container full of methanol at those
temperatures and pressures is a little
worrying so this is probably the most
dangerous experiment that I've ever
posted to YouTube so if you want to
flame me for that and go ahead I'm
probably not going to try this again I'm
just kind of happy to get through this
without any problems and we'll probably
try something different next time so
these aerogels here are the ones that I
made with the supercritical co2 method
and this is an aerogel that I just made
today with the supercritical methanol
method and there's less shrinkage so one
of the problems I had with supercritical
co2 is that these aerogels came out with
a smaller volume than when they went in
you can see the diameter here and
compare it to the diameter of of this
one that I just made it's this is a
bigger piece even though they came out
of the same mold so I'm not really sure
exactly why that is but as you can see
there's still quite a lot of cracking
involved but getting a lower density is
definitely helpful this piece has a
density of about 100 milligrams per
cubic centimeter which is I think better
than quite a bit better than the
previous gels that I've made but it
still could be much lower
so this piece isn't even lowered this
this one's too hard to measure the
volume of but it's coming in at 250
milligrams for this piece so that's
probably the lowest density aerogel that
I've made yet i reconfigured my pipe
fittings into a sealed chamber
with just a valve at the bottom and a
compression fitting at the top and I
just plugged up the other hole because I
didn't need it and then from that
compression fitting I made a small gauge
in valve manifold and added another
compression fitting so that I could vent
the chamber remotely so the idea is that
putting a valve and a gauge on the top
of the chamber would be a problem
because the chamber is going to be at
500 degrees F which would probably melt
the valve and make it very difficult to
remelted and make it very difficult to
control the valve so I removed those
pieces from the chamber just for ease of
use I mixed up a few different batches
of aerogel
same basic method with teemo's but this
time I made different densities so I
started off with the typical density the
same recipe that I showed in my earlier
video that's listed on aerogel org and
then I increased the amount of methanol
or decreased the amount of teemo's
relative to the other chemicals to make
a less dense gel now the problem is the
less dense gels didn't hold their shape
so if the original density the
high-density aerogel I was able to use
my syringe cast method and formed the
gel in a syringe and then inverted the
syringe over the container full of
methanol to eject the aerogel but the
lower density aerogel is just cracked
apart you know kind of as usual as I was
ejecting them from the syringe so I
think in the future if I try another
batch I will use like a metal container
to form the aerogel and then put the
whole metal container inside the drying
chamber so they don't have to unmold it
similarly to the co2 drying method the
next step is to close the chamber off
and start raising the temperature the
pressure will also rise because we've
got a fixed volume inside there and as
the temperature goes up the pressure
will as well and when I got to about
2000 psi I started venting the chamber
just to keep the pressure down even
though we hadn't gotten to the critical
point yet
I could let out some of the volume just
to keep the total pressure lower and I
set this up so that I could vent the
vapor coming out of the chamber into a
flask of water and the water would
ensure that all the methanol vapor
coming out of the chamber would be
liquid instead of just gas floating
around the room if you have a slow leak
in the chamber there's going to be a lot
of methanol vapor coming out and in a if
you were indoors here so that that could
be a problem
originally I thought quite a bit about
how to heat the chamber the best way I
thought about putting it in a toaster
oven because then I could control the
temperature of the air inside the
tumbler inside the toaster oven very
accurately but I decided against that
idea because it's a very small volume
inside the toaster oven so if the
chamber were leaking methanol vapor it
would build up really quickly in the
toaster oven and be an explosion hazard
so the next best thing I thought I was
to use an electric heating element and
just wrap it around the chamber and
allow venting to you know air flow to
occur so if there were a slow leak it
would just vent off into the shop but
again I didn't like the sound of that
because it might be hard to identify
such a leak so I ended up just using the
torch my thinking was that if there were
a slow leak it would just ignite as it
was coming out of the chamber
and I would at least be aware of it
right away it was a big leak that could
be a problem after I reached the
critical point which is four hundred
sixty degrees F at around 1200 psi for
methanol I started releasing the
pressure and continued to apply heat to
keep the temperature above 460 and
allowed the pressure to come down slowly
once the pressure is below the critical
point about 1200 and the temperature is
still above 460 we can start venting the
chamber more quickly because we know
that there's just gas inside there all
of the supercritical drying has occurred
here's one thing that I didn't expect
when I dumped out the contents of the
chamber the aerogels that were kind of
near the top
looked you know okay I mean they're
cracked but at least you know they're
they're normal looking aerogel but these
stuff at the bottom of the chamber was
kind of mixed in with this ash kind of a
slip or something at the bottom and when
I had done is I had put this aluminum
spacer into the bottom so that the
aerogels that were sitting on the bottom
of the chamber wouldn't fall down into
the valve that's at the bottom so I
don't know what's going on here but
apparently aluminum reacts with
supercritical methanol I think I can't
even remember but I'm pretty sure that I
put a piece of Windows screen inside
here to cover up these holes just
aluminum windows screen and it's gone so
I I don't know what happened there but
I'd be interested you know if you guys
have some knowledge about how
supercritical methanol reacts with
aluminum it looks like it just burned
away although I don't know the chemistry
involved okay well like you see I think
I've pretty much done with aerogel there
might be one or two other small things
I'm going to try but next up on the list
is vacuum frying someone someone in my
comments section posted a suggestion
about Trader Joe's vacuum fried fruit so
this is pretty interesting if you put
food into oil and then lower the
pressure and raise the temperature you
can fry it at a lower temperature than
you could in atmospheric pressure so I'm
gonna try that and then of course if
that's interesting what about high
pressure frying you could also put the
food into oil raise the temperature and
raise the pressure to prevent the water
from boiling so I'm gonna be having some
fun experimenting with that stuff and I
of course I will document and make some
videos alright see you next time bye
